For me ne schal no whar: of him wite bote ho so wole lie
Ruben was his fader icliped: his moder Thiborie
Þis ruben in ierusalem: wonede mid his wyue
Þeȝ here sone a schrewe were: hi were of gode lyue
As þis Ruben bi his wyf: aniȝt ileye hadde
Harde metinge his wyf mette: whar of he sore adradde
Hire þoȝte heo hadde ibore a child: þat al þe wordle was loþ
And al þe wordle him a-cursede: and was wiþ him wroþ
And þat acursed he schulde euere beo: while þe wordle stode
And al his cun me cursie wolde: for such a liþer vode
Þis wyf was wel sore adrad: to hire louerd heo tolde anon
ȝe, he seide, hit is þe mase: and also hit wole gon
Wel ic wot, quaþ þis gode wyf: if ic am mid childe
Þat hit is tokning of a bern: liþer and vnmylde
Þis wyf rekenede þe tyme: and swiþe heo gan iwite
And yfele þat he was mid childe: and þulke tyme biȝite
Sorie heo was and sore of drad: hire freondes heo tolde fore
Hi nuste what hem was to done: þo þat child was ibore
Loþ hem was to murþrie: here flesch and here blod
And loþ a bern to norischie: so liþer and vngod
¶ So þat he seȝe: a barayl atte laste
Þer inne hi dude þis liþer child: and amidde þe see hit caste
Þe see him hurlede vp and doun: as a liþer clot
Siþþe hit caste him alond: vpe þe yle of Cariot
Þerfore Iudas cariot: euere icleped he was
For in þe yle of Cariot: ifonde he was bi cas
Þe king and þe quene of þe lond: togadere were longe
Ac hi no child for no þing: bituene hem nemiȝte afonge
So þat þe quene ȝeode adai: and pleide bi þe stronde
In þe yle of Cariot: þe liþere bern heo fonde
Þo heo seȝ hit was a child: manlich and fair
Glad heo was and hopede: of him to habbe an heire
Heo let hit witie in preuite: mid childe heo hire makede
Þe king and al þe lond also: þerof were wel glade
Sone þe tyme heo nom forþ: þat þe child scholde beon ibore
Me schowede forþ þe liþere bern: glad was þe king þerfore
¶ Þo seȝ hit fair and hende: he let hit nemne Iudas
Hit nis noȝt al god þat is fair: isene þer hit was
Þat child was ido in gode warde: as kinges sone scholde
Sone hit ful þerafterward: as oure louerd hit wolde
Þat þe quene mid childe was: of hir louerd biȝite
Glad were boþe king and quene: þo hi hit miȝte wite
So þat heo hadde a knaue child: þat fair and gentyl was
Þe quene vpe him hire hurte dude: and þe lasse vpe Iudas
¶ Þe children waxe swiþe wel: Iudas bigan sone
To do liþere and qued ouer al: as him was to done
Children þat he com to: he wolde smyte and bete
And breke here armes and here heued: and þat god lete
To þe kinges sone he hadde enuie: for he was iloued more
Of þe quene þan he were: hit of þoȝte him sore
Þerfore he alto-beot þat child: whan he miȝte hit one wite
Ac þe quene him beot sore aȝen: whan heo hit miȝte vnderȝite
Ac þerfore nolde he neuere bileue: for neuere ichasted he nas
So þat þe quene vpbreid adai: þat he fyndling was
After þulke tyme þis liþere þing: þat child hatede ynouȝ
He awaitede his tyme wel: and priueliche hit slouȝ
¶ Þo ne þerste he no leng abide: leste he hadde his dom
Stilleliche he wende to ierusalem: me nuste whar he bicom
Þer was pilatus: of þe lond Iustise
Þis Iudas anon vnder him: leuede in seruise
So wel he louede him anon: þat styward he him made
Of al his þing, and het his men: do þat he bade
Þat o schrewe wiþ þat oþer: maister was as riȝt is
For ech þing loueþ his iliche: so saiþ þe boc iwys
For þeȝ in al a contray: bote tueie schrewes nere
ȝut hi wolde felawes beo: if he to-gadere were
¶ So þat þis tuei schrewen: þe louerd and þe stiward
Adai ȝeode alone pleye: vnder an orchard
Swiþe faire aples: pilatus iseȝ þerinne
Clembe ouer he bad Iudas: and some þerof iwinne
Iudas brac þe ȝard anon: and sone was in ibroȝt
His owe fader orchard hit was: ac naþeles he nuste hit noȝt
Com þe gode man þat was his fader: and eschte him what he were
And bi was leue he brac his ȝard: and what he dude þer
Iudas seide ic wole her beo: maugre þi teþ bifore
And of þis applen habbe and bere: þeȝ þu hit haddest iswore
¶ Þis gode man was anuyed: of þis liþer answere
Þe schrewe he misdude aȝen: he nemiȝte noleng forbere
So þat hi neme aiþer oþer bi þe top: and makede stronge wounde
Þe schrewe was strengere þan his fader: and broȝte him sone to g[r]unde
So þat he smot him wiþ a ston: bihynde in þe pate
Þat al þe sculle to-daschte: þe brayn ful out þerate
So þat he slouȝ his owe fader: and þo me miȝte wite
Þat his moder mette of him soþ: þo he was biȝite
ȝut were his fader betere: habbe ibroȝt him of dawe
As sone as he was ibore: þan he hadde him aslawe
Of þ'aplen þat þe schrewe whan: and of þe peren also
And bar pilatus and tolde him: hou he hadde ido
¶ Pilatus wende anoþer daie: to þe gode manes house
And ȝaf Iudas al his god: and makede him wedden his spouse
For he was maister & Iustise: he miȝte do vnriȝt ynouȝ
Þo weddede þe schrewe his owe moder: and his fader aslouȝ
¶ As þis gode wyf lai aniȝt: bi hire schrewe louerd þere
Heo gan to sike swiþe sore: he eschte whi hit were
¶ Certes, sire, quaþ þis wyf: wel aniȝte ic sike sore
Wo and sorewe me comeþ to: none womman more
Glad ne bliþe ne worþe ic neuer: whan ic me biþenche
For ic nadde neuere sone bote on: and him ic let adrenche
Siþþe ic fond mie louerd aslawe: y not in whiche wise
And myn vnþonkes ic am iwedded: wiþ strengþe of þe iustise
Þo Iudas ihurde þis: sorie he was ynouȝ
Certes, he seide, ic am þi sone: and mi fader ic aslouȝ
Þo was þis gode wyf soriere: þan heo euere were
Sone, heo seide, what mowe we do: þat we ischryue nere
¶ Iudas ihurde of oure louerd telle: þat he an vrþe ȝeode
Þat he halp menie man: in siknesse and in neode
Þurf his moder red to schrifte: to oure louerd he wende
Repentant he was and wilnede: his lyf to amende
So þat he suede oure louerd longe: to wite of his manere
Oure louerd him makede his disciple: to beo apostles ifere
Siþþe oure louerd him makede apostle: to fondi his mod
And siþþe pursberer of his pans: to spene al his god
For meni men ȝyue oure louerd god: þat were of gode þoȝt
To susteynie his apostles: oþer nadde he noȝt
Ac þo Iudas wiþinne was: and his miȝte founde
Of oure louerdes god þat he wiste: he stal al to grounde
Whan he miȝte of eche þing: þe teoþing he wolde stele
A schrewe he was al his lyf: y ne maie no leng hele
Wel wiste oure louerd þas: and al his liþer dede
Ac naþeles he moste fulfille: þat þe prophetes sede
¶ Seinte Marie Magdaleyne: to oure louerd com
To-fore his swete passioun: and moche oignement wiþ hire nom
His fet heo wosch wiþ hire teres: and wipede wiþ hire her
Wiþ þis swete oignement: heo smired oure louerd þer
Iudas of þoȝte þis ille: for hit moche worþ was
And seide þat hit was vuele ido: þat hit isold nas
Þreo hondred pans hit was worþ: and þermide me miȝte fille
Menie pore man afingred: ho so hit moste sille
Þat he seide for he wolde: if þe boxes hadde ibeon isolde
Habbe ispend and to him: þe teoþing iholde
Þe teoþing þerof was þrettie pans: sore him of-þoȝte þerfore
Þat so menie pans of his þeofþe: scholde fram him beo ilore
Þerfore oure louerd for þrettie pans: he solde mid vnriȝte
Þat he þe teoþing of þulke boxes: to him keouerie miȝte
Him suede eche liþeri þewe: for he louede baret and stryf
He was strong þeof and man quellere: and also he endede his lyfe
And suche men schulde anhonge beo: and þo noman hit nolde do
Him silf he heng vp a treo: for such deþ he scholde to
His wombe to-berste amidde atuo: þo he schulde deye
His gvttes fulle to grounde: menie men hit iseye
Þer wende out a liþer gost: atte mouþ hit nemiȝte
For he custe er oure louerd: þerwiþ mid vnriȝte
Nou swete louerd þat þurf Iudas: isold wer to þe treo
Schuld ous fram þe liþere stede: þer we weneþ þat he beo: Amen.

DIV2.HEAD: XXIV. PILATE.

LG.L: Pilatus was a liþer man: and com of liþer more
Bituene a king and a fol womman: in spousbreche ibore
Þe king Tirus was an heȝ man: and of grete fame
Bi a melewardes douȝter he lai: Pila was hire name
And biȝat on hire vnder þe querne: þe liþere bern bi cas
Þe meleward þat hire fader was: atus ihote was
For þe douȝter þat het Pile: and þe fader Atus
Of here beire name me makede anne: and clipede him pilatus
Þe child wax and wel iþeȝ: and þo hit was of þreo ȝere
Þe moder hit sende to his fader: for he was of gret poer
Þe king hit louede swiþe wel: and let hit wel lere
Bi þe quene he hadde anoþer child: boþe in one ȝere
Þat child þat was riȝt biȝute: and pilatus also
To norisschi and to lere wel: to-gadere were ido
As hi wexe hi toppede ofte: þer nas bituene hem no loue
Ac þat child riȝt biȝute: euer was aboue
¶ Pilatus awaitede his poynt: and þoȝte to ȝulde his while
He stal adai stilleliche: and slouȝ þat child wiþ gyle
¶ Þo þe king þis ihurde: he was sorie ynouȝ
He nuste what do wiþ þe schrewe: þat his riȝt sone so slouȝ
He þoȝte if he hit slowe: þat hit were doble wo
And þat he nemiȝte bliþe beo: whan he him iseȝe owhar go
¶ Þ'emperour to him sende: after truage of his londe
Þe king him biþoȝte hou he miȝte best: paye him of his sonde
Pilatus he sende þider: as hit were in ostage
For þ'emperour him scholde sle: whan him faillede of his truage
He sende him word þat he nadde: children bote him on
And for al þe god alyue: he nolde his lyf forgon
And bote he at his daye: sende his truage
Hi his sone do what he wolde: as riȝt is bi ostage
¶ Þemperour him louede moche: ac of his schreuhede nuste he noȝt
Þe kinges sone of france ek: was in hostage þider ibroȝt
He was bet biloued þan pilatus: þeȝ hi felawes were
And for þat on was god and þat oþer schrewe: gode felawes neuere hi nere
Þe schrewe awaitede wel his tyme: for he was fel ynouȝ
Bituene hem silue stilleliche: his felawe he slouȝ
Þemperour him nom anon: he nuste what wiþ him do
He wolde him sle, ac his consail: ne ȝaf him noȝt þerto
And seide he was toward: swiþe hardie man mid alle
Of a such man miȝte moche god: in to al þe contray bifalle
¶ Schulle we lete quaþ þ'emperour: a manquellere alyue go
Sire sire quaþ þis oþer: þu hast menie a fo
And such man if he bileueþ forþ: gret god maie þe do
And if lawe of londe nele: þat þu him lete so go
Wel þu wost þat in þe yle of Ponce: schrewen þer beoþ ynowe
Þer com neuere Iustise: þat hi sone ne slowe
Þerfore þu miȝt him sende þider: to beo Iustise of þulke yle
And bote he beo queyntere þan enie oþer: he ne scapeþ noȝt a gyle
And if he þat lond chasteþ wel: and bringeþ vnder fote
He worþ man wiþoute peer: if he duri mote
¶ Þo pilatus was þider isend: he wiste wel þe gyle
And þe maner enquerede of þe lond: þo he cam in to þe yle
He spac faire and mylde: and was euere stille
Wiþ fair speche and quentise: he hadde of hem his wille
Hi dude al after his wille: and hulde him euere Iustise
Þer nemiȝte so neuere non: beo in none wise
¶ Þo þ'emperour ihurde þat he miȝte: þat liþere folc so þewe
He ne huld non so queynte man: as he huld þe schrewe
Of his queyntise me spac wide: bi daye and bi nyȝte
Hou he amaistrede þe yle of ponce: as neuere no man ne miȝte
For he amaistrede and ascapede: þe yle of ponce so wel
Ponce pilatus me him clipeþ: in crede and godspel
¶ Þe king herodes þat was: þo king bi kynde
Of þe lond of ierusalem: and of Galilee and ynde
Of pilatus he hurde ynouȝ: of his wit and his queyntise
Glad and bliþe he wolde beo: to habbe such a Iustise
Noble ȝiftes he him ȝaf: and fondede in alle wise
If he wolde out of þat lond: and leue in his seruise
So þat pilatus com to him: and such consail hi toke
Þat more þan half his kynedom: he tok him to loke
To beo maister of ierusalem: and also of ynde
In his owe lond he athuld: Galilee of his kynde
Þo pilatus hadde þer longe: þe maistrie fur and nher
He gan to cuþe what he was: þo he seȝ his poer
For ech schrewe wole abide his tyme: to cuþe his felonie
He gaderede tresour and oþer god: ynouȝ in his baillie
And wende to Cezar þemperour: þat was maister ouer þe kinge
Of tresour and oþer god ynouȝ: largeliche he gan him bringe
And ȝaf him wiþ þat he moste: þe baillie holde þere
Of him as he dude of herodes: his kynedom þeȝ hit were
¶ þemperour þat was þe kinges louerd: sone him biþoȝte
And gladliche nom þe tresour: þat pilatus him broȝte
And grantede pilatus al þat lond: to holde bi maistrie
Þat he huld er of herodes: þer was gret trecherie
He wende aȝe to ierusalem: and to ynde also
As louerd he dude alle his hestes: þo he cam þerto
Herodes sende after him: to accountie after wille
Pilatus spac þurf þemperour: and ne ȝaf noȝt worþ afille
Þo herodes iseȝ þe trecherie: and þe liþere falshede
He huld him bitrayd þurf felonie: he nuste what to rede
Þo he seȝ þat he ne miȝte: vndo þemperoures dede
Pilatus he acursede ilome: for his liþere falshede
And þo he ne miȝte him oþer do: bote wraþþe him bar mid riȝte
So gret wraþþe hem was bituene: þat no tonge hit telle ne miȝte
Þe wraþþe ilaste forte oure louerd: to deþe scholde go
Ac for aiþer to oþer sende: acorded hi were þo
¶ Þe while pilatus in his lond: louerd and sire was
Iudas þat oure louerd solde: to him com bi cas
His steward he him makede anon: gode freond hi were
For tuei schrewen wolleþ freond beo: þeȝ no mo men nere
Iudas was þer his steward: forte he his fader aslouȝ
And forte he wedde his owe moder: wiþ grete strenȝþe and wouȝ
¶ Suþþe god was ynome: and schulde beo to deþe ido
Pilatus þurf þe gywene wille: him demde þerto
For þe gywes in ierusalem: in here poer him nome
Þerfore hi ne miȝte him quelle noȝt: bote þurf his dome
Longe after þat he was ded: he repentede him ilome
He ne þerste noȝt for þemperour: þerfore come at Rome
Ac euere him huld at Ierusalem: among þe gywes faste
Ac sore he dradde þemperour: þat he him slowe atte laste
Longe hit ful þerafterward: þat þemperour was sek
In strong vuele and wel long: þat he nas noman ilek
Leches he let fecche wide: ac him ne miȝte hele non
So þat his o messager: to ierusalem com gon
Longe and wide he eschte þer: after sum god leche
To a womman he com þat het veronike: þat heo scholde him to sum on teche
Allas, quaþ þe womman: if þu haddest hider igon
Þe while þe prophete her was: þi wille hadde beo idon
¶ A whar, quaþ þe messager þo: þe prophete beo bicome
Certes, quaþ veronike: þe gywes him habbeþ ynome
To deþe him hi brouȝte on þe rode: þurf pilatus dome
Þerfore he ne þerste neuer eft: bifore ȝou come at Rome
Þe while þe prophete her was: gret ioye ic hadde midde alle
Him to neȝ beo: if hit miȝte so bifalle
And þo y ne miȝte neȝ him beo: ic him bad a bone
Þat ich miȝte ofte his forme iseo: he me grantede sone
¶ Mi keuerchief ic him bitok: and he wond hit aboute his face
Þat ech man miȝte wel iseo: his miȝte and his grace
For þer he leuede his owe forme: þat in his face was
In ech poynt þo he hit me tok: þat no defaute þer nas
Þulke forme is me bileued: þat ich miȝte igladed beo
Þurf þe siȝt þat is him so iliche: whan y ne mai him silue iseo
Hadde þi louerd þemperour: þe forme iseȝe ene
Ich wot he were hol anon: and of his vuel clene
Dame, mercie, quaþ þe messager: maie þulke ymage oȝt
For enie gold oþer siluer siluer: is repeated in the MS.: to þemperour beo ibroȝt
Þat nis noȝt, quaþ þis wyf: for al his gold iwis
Bugge ne miȝte þe leste hurne: þat þeron is
Ac ic wole, quaþ þe wyfe: wiþ þe to him wende
If oure louerd him wole bote: þurf his forme him sende
¶ Heo wende forþ wiþ þis messager: and þo heo com to Rome
Þemperour hi tolde al þis: þo hi to him come
¶ Anon þo he þe ymage iseȝ: he was ol anon
He honourede wel veroníke: heo ne moste fram him gon
Þe ymage he athuld þat hit ne com: neuereft out of Rome
In seint peteres churche hit is: as men iseoþ ilome
¶ Þo eschte he whar oure louerd were: and whar he siþþe bicome
Veronike him seide hou þe gywes: to stronge deþe him nome
And hou pilatus his Iustise: þe dom ȝaf þerto
¶ Ou liþere man, quaþ þemperour: haþ he itake on so
Assentede he to þe gywes: and nas noȝt of here lawe
Ich wole if ic maie to him come: anhonge him oþer todrawe
Allas þulke holi man: þat he let bringe of dawe
Ich wot þe gywes beoþ wel liþer: hi wolde beo þerof fawe
In faire manere he let sende: after pilatus sone
Þat he come to him as to his louerd: as riȝt was to done
Ac pilatus sende ane lettre: to his louerd er
Þat he forȝeue him his wraþþe: þat he to him ber
And þat he was gulteles of þe deþ: þat me vpe him sede
And þat þe gywes him slowe: al wiþoute his rede
Ac a strong tempest in þe see: his messager gan dryue
In-to þe lond of galilee: and þer he gan ariue
Ac vaspasian þat was þer maister: þe messager faste nom
So þat neȝ þemperour: þe messager neuere ne com
¶ Þo þemperoures messager: to pilatus was icome
And pilatus hadde of him: his erande ynome
He wende þat his owe messager: to þemperour hadde iwend
And þat he hadde forȝeue him his wraþþe: and after him isend
Oure louerdes curtel he dude on: þat he wiste euer wel
Þat vnsued was of þred: as hit saiþ in þe godspel
Wiþ wel glade chere: he wende to þemperour
And grette him þo he com him to: wiþ wel gret honoure
¶ So wroþ wiþ noman vnder sonne: þemperour nas bifore
As he wiþ pilatus was: for his deþ he hadde iswore
And for he hadde oure lordes curtel: on whan he bifore him com
His hurte was al swaged: wiþ grete ioie he him nom
He makede mid him al þe ioye: þat man miȝte mid oþer do
For virtu of þe holi curtel: and his men also
Anon so he was out of his siȝt: his oþ he swor anon
Þat to stronge deþe he wolde him bringe: if he miȝte him of gon
Ac gret ioye he makede mid alle: whan he to him com
And euere whan he fram him was: he iuggede him stronge dom
Þis maner ileste longe: þat alle þat ihurde þis cas
Wondrede moche of þemperour: þat he vnstable was
So atte laste þis pilatus: as oure louerde hit wolde
His curtel he stripte of bi cas: as he neuere ne scholde
And com so bifore þemperour: and he anon him nom
He swor his more oþ anon: þat he to wroþere hele þer com
Sai, he seide, þu wrecche man: sai what hastou ido
Slowe þu þe holi prophete: to wroþere hele dudestou so
¶ Certes sire, quaþ pilatus: y ne dude him noȝt to deþe
Beo iknowe, quaþ þemperour: for þu miȝt as esþe
Bote þe liþere gywes, quaþ pilatus: to þe deþe him broȝte
Wiþoute þe, quaþ þemperour: neuere such þing hi ne wroȝte
¶ Certes sire, quaþ pilatus: y ne maie noȝt ofsake þis
Þat y ne demde him to deþe: ac ic moste nede iwis
For þenqueste vpe him seide: þat he destruyde oure lawe
And lawe ȝifþ þat alle suche: me scholde bringe of dawe
And ic þer þat þi iustise was: þurf þin heste and þi rede
Moste nede ȝyue þe dom: whan þenqueste sede
¶ Whan þu vnderȝete, quaþ þemperour: þe gywene falshede
Whi naddestou ispeke þer aȝe: and desturbed þe liþere dede
God hit wot, quaþ pilatus: and ierusalem also
Þat ic was þer aȝen bi mie miȝte: þat he nere to deþe ido
Ac hi were vpe him alle so faste: þat me ne miȝt mid no lawe
Whan þenqueste passede: bote he were ibroȝt of dawe
¶ If þu ne miȝtest mid riȝte him sauue: þemperour þo sede
Hou þerstestou wiþoute mie red: do such a liþere dede
Certes sire, quaþ pilatus: y ne maie wiþsigge noȝt
Þat ic þerof ne misdude: in gulte ic am ibroȝt
And me schal bi þe, quaþ þemperour: as bi a gultie man do
Þu schalt passi bi iugement: for þu toke on so
In strong prisoun and swiþe durk: sone he let him caste
Þat he ne seȝ fot ne honde: he let him bynde faste
So longe he laie in prisoun: in hunger and in pyne
Þat his lymes clonge awei: his bodie gan al fordwyne
He hadde leouere his deþ þeran: his lymes so forclonge to noȝte
So hi dude alle tofore here deþ: þat oure louerde to deþe broȝte
¶ A dai as þe gailer: into prisoun com
Pilatus cride so dulfulliche: þat gret deol to him he nom
"Haue reuþe of me, sire, he seide: for þin owe gentrice
Wel þu wost knyȝt ic am: and while was heȝ Iustice
And nou ic her clynge awei: and no siȝt iseo wiþ eye
Let me enes per charite: iseo siȝt er ic deye"
Þe gayler hadde reuþe of him: such man he hadde ibeo
And of prisoun ladde him out: þe worlde forto seo
¶ Þo pilatus com to liȝte: as þe boc haþ itold
And iseȝ his bodie alforswarted: his hurte ful ful cold
"Allas he seide þis dai abide: þat ich euere com in liȝt
Sire Renald for þi curteisie: grante me ane bone
ȝif me an appel to ete: for ic hit maie do sone"
Þe gayler him tok an appel: he seide hit was vnriȝt
Vnpared an appel take: an heȝ man oþer a kniȝt
Such wrecche as ic nou am: ic was while heȝ Iustise
Len me a knyf þis appel to parie: for þin owe gentrise
Þo þe gayler him tok a knyfe: him silue he slouȝ anon
And smot him deope in þe bodie: and lai ded as a ston
Þo þe teþinge com to þemperour: þat bodie he let take
And caste hit wiþoute þe toun: among olde walles forsake
Þer ne wende noman þerforþ: aboute in none side
Þat he nas lame oþer wod: oþer sum auentoure him gan bitide
Þer was þundre and liȝtninge: and gret tempest þer aboute
Þat hi were witles and adrad: þat hi ne þerste no whar at-route
So þat þemperour let take: þe wrecche licame atte laste
And bere hit to þe watere of tybre: and þerinne hit caste
Þo com þer a gret tempest: þat þer aboute wel wide
Þat schipes adreynte þere menie on: þer aboute in eche side
¶ Al þe contray þer aboute hem dradde: and nom hem to rede
And in-to a watere fur fram men: þis licame gonne lede
Bituene hulles and wyldernisse: and þerinne hi him caste
Þe þundre smot þer anon: and þe liȝtinge wel faste
Þat bodie flet vp and doun: icast her and þere
Mid weder and tempest of water: þat ech man hadde fere
Amidde þe water þer stod a roche: þo þe licame was þer neȝ
Þe roche clef amidde atuo: as al þat folc iseȝ
And as an arewe schet of a bwe: þat bodie schet þerinne
Þe roche schet to-gadere anon: þo þat bodie was wiþ-inne
And þe wrecche bodie þer lyþ: ȝut to þis day
Moche wo ȝut þer is þer aboute: as me iseo maie
Þus pilatus endede his lyf: as he wel wel worþe was
God schulde ech cristenene man: fram so dulful cas. Amen.

Mus. ht; also a final e after the t of rent, tent, hent, ment, l. 6, 7, 9, 11. It has also more capitals for the nouns; and more metrical points, which are printed here. wode syde.
In a launde. þer i. was lent.
Wlanke deor. on grounde gan glide.
And lyouns raunpyng. vppon bente.
Beores. woluus. with mouþes wide.
Þe smale bestes Beestes.. þei al to-rent.
Þer haukes vnto þare heore. pray þei hyde.
Of whuche. to on. i. toke goode tok god. tent.
A merlyon. a brid hedde had. hent.
And in hir hire. foot. heo gan hit bringe.
Hit couþe not speke. but þus hit ment.
How merci passeþ alle þinge.
Merci was in þat. bryddes Briddes. Muvnde.
But þerof kneuȝ. þe hauk non.
For in hire foot. he heo. gan hit bynde.
And heolde hit stille. as eni ston.
Heo dud after. þe cours of kynde.
And fleiȝ in-to a treo anon.
Þorw kynde. þe brid gan Merci fynde.
For on þe morwe. heo let hit gon.
Ful stille .i. stod. my self al on.
To herken. how þat bryd gan synge
A-wey wol wende. boþe murthe and moon.
And Merci passeþ. strengþe and riht.
Mony a wyse. seo we may.
God ordeynet ordeyned. Merci. most of miht.
To beo a-boue. his werkes ay.
Whou deore Ihesu. schal beo be. diht.
To demen vs. at domes day.
Vr sunne wol beo. so muche in siht.
We schul not wite. what we schul say.
Ful fresliche fersliche.. riht wol vs affray.
And blame vs for. vr mislyuyng.
Þen dar non persone p'se.. for vs to pray.
But Merci. passeþ alle þinge þing..
¶ Riht wolde sle vs. for vr sunne synne..
Miht wol don. execucion.
And rihtwis god. þenne Rihtwyse god. þen. wol bigynne.
Forto Forte. reherse vs. þis resoun.
I made þe Mon. ȝif þat þou mynne.
Of feture. liche. myn owne fasoun.
And after crepte. in-to þi kynne.
And for þe suffred passioun.
Of þornes kene. þen was þe croun.
Ful scharpe. vppon. myn hed standyng.
Myn herte B.M.hert. blood. ran from me doun.
And i. forȝaf þe. alle þinge þing..
Myn herte B.M.hert. blood. for þe gan blede.
To buye þe. from þe fendes blake B.M.feondes bolde..
And i. forȝaf þe. þi mysdede.
What hast þou suffred. for my sake.
Me hungred. þou woldest not me fede.
Ne neuer my furst. ne woldestou slake.
Whon .i. of herborwe. hedde gret nede.
Þou woldest not. to þin hous me take.
Þou seȝe me .a. monge todes blake.
Ful longe. in harde prisoun lyng.
Let seo what vnswere. constou make.
Where were Wher weore. þou kynde. in eny þing.
And hou .i. whenched quenched.. al þi care.
Lyft vp þin eȝe eiȝe.. and þou maiȝt se.
My woundes wete. blodi al bare.
As i. was rauht rauȝt.. on roode tre.
Þou seȝe me. for defaute forfare.
In sekenes. and in pouerte.
ȝrt ȝit. of þi good. woldestou not spare.
Ne ones come. to visite me.
Al eorþly þinge þing.. i. ȝaf to þe.
Boþe beest and fysche fisch.. and foul fleoyng.
And tolde þe. hou þat charite.
And Merci. passeþ alle þing.
¶ Hou myhtou. eny Merci haue.
Þat neuer desiredest. non to do.
Þou seȝe me naked. and cloþes craue. The next four lines are from the Bodleian copy, and are not in the Brit. Mus. one.
Barehed. and Barefot. gan I. go.
On me þou vochedest no þing saue.
But beede me wende. þi wones fro.
Þou seȝe me ded. aboue to graue.
¶ On bere. seuen dayes and mo.
For luytel dette. i. ouȝte þe þo.
Þou forbed. my buryinge buriȝing..
Þi Pater noster. seide not so.
For Merci passeþ. alle þinge.
¶ Þeose are þe werkes of Merci. seuene.
Of whuche. crist wol vs areyne.
Þat alle schul stoney. wiþ þat steuene.
Þat euer tresoun. mihte ateyne.
For here heer. but yf ȝif. we make vs euene.
Þer may no miht. ne ȝiftes ȝeyne.
Þen Þenne. to þe kyng of heuene.
Þe bok seiþ. þat we schul seyne.
Wher hastou lord. in prisoun leyne.
Whon were Whonne weore. þou. in eorþe dwellyng.
Whon seȝe we þe. in suche peyne.
Whon askedst þou. vs eny þing.
¶ Whon ȝe seȝe. oþer ouþer.. blynd. or lame.
Þat for my loue. asked ȝou ouȝt.
Al þat ȝe duden. in my myn. name.
Hit was to me. boþe dede deede. & þouht.
But ȝe þat hated. cristendame.
And of my wraþþe. neuer ne rouht ȝt for ht..
ȝour seruise schal. be ben. endeles schame.
Helle fuyr. þat slakes nouht ȝt for ht..
And ȝe. þat with my blood .i. bouht ȝt for ht.
Þat loued me. in ȝoure lyuynge.
ȝe schul haue. þat ȝe haue souht ȝt for ht..
Merci þat passeþ alle þinge.
¶ Þis tyme schal tyde. hit is no nay.
And wel is hym. þat haþ þat grace.
For to plese. his god to pay.
And Merci secheþ seche.. while he haþ space.
For beo vr mouþe. crommed ? quommed. with wt. clay.
Wormes blake. wol vs enbrace.
Þenne is too late. Mon. in goode fay.
To seche to amende. of þi trespace.
With wt. mekenes þou may. heuene purchase.
Oþer meede. þar þe non bryng.
But knowe þi god. in vche a case.
And loue hym best. of eny þing.
¶ To god a and. mon. were holden meste.
To loue. and his wraþþe eschuwe.
Now is non. so vnkuynde a beeste.
Þat lasse doþ. þat weore hym duwe.
For beestes and foules. more and leeste.
Þe cours of kuynde kynde.. alle þei suwe.
And whon whonne. we breken. godes heste.
Aȝeynes kuynde. we ben vn-trewe.
For kuynde wolde. þat we hym knewe.
And dradde hym moste most.. in vre doinge doing..
Hit is no riht. þat he vs rewe.
But Merci passeþ. alle þinge.
¶ Now harlotrie y for ie.. for murþe is holde.
And vertues turnen tornen.. in-to vice.
And symonye. haþ chirches solde.
And lawe is waxen. couetise.
Vr feiþ is frele. to flecche and folde.
For treuþe is put. to luytel prise.
Vr Vre. god. is glotonye. and golde.
Dronkenes. lecherie y for ie. and dyse.
Lo here heer. vr lust. and vr Vre. likyng.
ȝet ȝif we wole. repent repente. and rise.
Merci passeþ. alle þinge.
¶ Vnlustily. vr lyf we lede.
Monhod and we. twynne in two.
To heuene ne helle. take we non hede.
But on day come. a noþer go.
Who is a Maister. now but meede.
And pruude. þat wakened al vr wo.
We stunt noþer stunte neiþer.. for schame ne drede.
To teren vr god. from top to to.
For-swere his soule. his hert al-so herte also..
And alle þe Membres menbres.. þat we con cun. mynge.
Ful harde vengeaunce. wol falle o on. þo.
But Merci passeþ alle þing þinge..
¶ And corteis knihthod. and clergye.
Þat wont were vices. to forsake.
Are now so roted Rooted.. in rybaudye.
Þat oþer murthes. lust hem not make.
A wey is gentel. curtesye gentyl cortesye..
And lustines. his leue haþ take.
We loue so slouþe. and harlotrie.
We slepe. a as. swolle swyn in lake.
Þer wol no worschupe. with vs wake.
Til þat charyte. be made beo mad. a kyng.
And þenne schal. alle vre synnes þen schal. al vr synne. slake.
And Merci passeþ alle þing.
¶ I. Munge no more. of þis to ȝou.
Al þauȝ .i. kouþe. yf ȝif. þat .i. wolde.
For ȝe han herde herd wel.. whi and hou.
Bigon þis tale. þat .i. haue tolde.
And þis men knowen. wel i.-nouh.
For Merlions. feet ben colde.
Hit is heore heor. kuynde. on bank and bouh.
A. quik brid. to haue hauen. and holde.
From foot to foot. to flytte flutte. and folde.
To kepe hire. from clomesyng.
As i. an hauþorn. gan bi holde.
I. sauȝ my self. þe same þing.
Whon heo hedde holden. so al niht.
On morwe heo let hit gon a way.
Wheþer genteri gentrie. tauȝt hire. so or nouht
I. con not telle ȝou. in goode good. fay.
But god. as þu art ful of myȝt.
Þouȝ we plese þe. not to pay.
Graunt vs repentaunce. and respiȝt.
And schrift and hosel. or we day.
As þou art god. and Mon verray.
Þou beo vr help. at vr vre. endyng.
Byfore i for y. þi face. þat we may i for y. say i for y..
Now Merci passeþ alle þing þinge..

DIV2.HEAD: XXVI. A SONGE OF DEO GRACIAS. This and the following Songs, I had not time to compare with the Bodleian copy.

HEADNOTE.P: (Duplicate of Vernon MS., Brit. Mus., fol. 129, col. 1.)

LG.L: In a chirche. þere i. con knel.
Þis ender day. in on Morwenynge.
Me liked þe seruise. wondur wel.
For-þi þe lengore. con .i. lynge.
I seiȝ a clerk a boke forthe brynge.
Þat prikked was. in Mony a plas.
Fast he souht what be schulde synge.
And al was. Deo gracias.
Alle þe queristres in þat qwer.
On þat word. fast gon þei cri:
Þe noyse was goode. and .i. drouȝ neer.
And calde a prest ful priuely.
And seide syre. for ȝor curtesy.
Telle me ȝif ȝe haue spas.
What hit meneþ. and for whi.
ȝe singe. Deo gracias.
¶ In silke þat comely clerk. was clad.
And ouer a lettorne. leoned he.
And with his word. he made me glad.
And seide sone. i. schal telle þe.
Fadur and sone. in Trinite.
Þe holygost ground of vr graas.
Also ofte siþe. þonke we.
As we sei. Deo gracias.
¶ To þonke and blesse hym we be bounde.
With alle þe murþes þat mon may mynne.
For al þe world in wo was wounde.
Til þat he crepte. in-to vr kynne.
A louesum buirde. he lihte with-Inne.
Þe worþiest þat euer was.
And schedde hys blood for vr synne.
And þerfore. Deo gracias.
¶ Þen seide þe prest. sone bi þi leue.
I. most seye forþ my seruise.
I. prey þe take hit. nouht in greue.
For þou hast herd al my deuyse.
Bi cause whi. hit is clerkes wise.
And holichirche. Muynde of hit maas.
Vn-to þe prince so muche of pride.
Forto synge. Deo gracias.
¶ Out of þat chirche. i. went my way.
And on þat word. was al my þouht.
And twenti tymes. i. con say.
God graunt þat i. forȝete hit nouht.
Þouȝ .i. were out of bonechef brouht.
What help weore to me. to say allas.
In þe nome of god. what euer be wrouht.
I. schal seie. Deo gracias.
¶ In myschef and in bonchef boþe.
Þat word is goode to say and synge.
And not to wayle and to be wroþe.
Þauȝ al be nouht at vr likynge.
For langour schal not euer lynge.
And sumtyme plesaunce. wol ouerpas.
But ay in hope of amendynge.
I. schal say. Deo gracias.
A-Mende þat þu hast done amis.
And do wel þenne and haue no drede.
Wheþer so þou beo. in bale or blis.
Þi goode suffraunce. schal gete þe mede.
ȝif þou þi lyf in likyng lede.
Loke þou be kinde in vche a caas.
Þonke þi god ȝif þou wel spede.
With þis word. Deo gracias.
¶ ȝif god haþ ȝiue þe vertues mo.
Þen he haþ oþer two or þre.
Þenne i. rede þou rule þe so.
Þat Men may speke worschupe bi þe.
Be ferd of pruyde and bost þou fle.
Þi vertues let no fulþe defaas.
But kepe þe clene corteis and fre.
And þenk on. Deo gracias.
¶ ȝif þou be made an officer.
And art a Mon of Muche miht.
What cause þou demest. loke hit be cler.
And reue no Mon from hym his riht.
ȝif þou be strong and fers to fiht
For envye neuer mon þou chas
But drede þi god. boþe day and niht.
And þenke on. Deo gracias.
¶ ȝif we þis word in herte wol haue.
And ay in loue and leute leende.
Of crist bi couenaunt. we mowe craue.
Þat ioye þat schal neuer haue ende.
Out of þis world. when we schul wende.
In-to his paleys forto paas.
And sitte A-Monge his seyntes hende.
And þere synge. Deo gracias.

LG.L: Deus caritas est.
A deore god omnipotent:
Lord þou madest. boþe foul and best
On eorþe to Mon. þou here hit sent.
I. warne ȝow alle boþe more and leste.
Charite .i. rede þat ȝe hent.
For hit is cristes heste.
Þat schal come to þe iugement
¶ For whon he comeþ. at domes day
Þat al þis world. hit schal wel se.
Þe wikked he biddeþ to gon heore way.
In bittre penaunce for euere to be.
And to þe goode wol þat lord say
ȝe schul alle wende wiþ me.
In-to þe blysse for euer and ay.
Et qui manet in caritate.
¶ God þat made boþe heuene and helle.
Vr swete lord of Nazareth
Adam þat was. so fair of felle.
For his folyes. he suffred deth.
In god for soþe. he schal dwelle.
In charite ho so geth.
Hit is soþ. þat .i. ou telle.
Bi-holde and seo. In deo manet.
¶ Crist was toren vche a lym.
And on þe Roode. he was .i.-do.
Þe fende þat was. so derke and dym.
To þe crois he com þo.
Crist. al Charite is in hym.
Þere he ouercome vr fo.
Charite i. rede þat þou myn.
And þenne. Deus est in eo.
¶ Let Charite. nou a-wake.
And do hit. þer neode is.
Heuene forsoþe. þenne maiȝt þou take.
And come to þat riche blis.
Nou crist for his Modur sake.
Let vs neuer þis place mys.
And schilde vs from. þe feondes blake.
And sit deus in nobis.
¶ And charite .i. rede þat we bygynne.
As bifore alle oþer games.
And schruyue vs clene of vr synne.
For so dud petur Ion and Iames.
And þerfore god. hem dwelled withinne.
For þei weore alle. withouten oþer blames.
Crist let vs heuene wynne.
Et nos in ipso maneamus.
¶ God þat dwelleþ in gret solas.
In heuene þat riche regnyng.
And for vs þoled gret trespas.
Wondur muche at vre muntyng.
On þe Roode don he was.
In gret dispit icleped a kyng.
Þenkeþ nouþe. on deus caritas.
And brynge vs alle to goode endyng.

DIV2.HEAD: XXVIII. ANOTHER SONGE OF DEO GRACIAS.

HEADNOTE.P: (Duplicate of Vernon MS. Brit. Mus. fol. 129, col. 1.)

LG.L: Mi. word is Deo gracias.
In world wheþer me be wel or wo.
Hou schold. i. lauȝwe or sigge allas.
For leeue me wel. hit lasteþ o.
And þouȝ hit greue. hit wol ouer go.
As þouht chaungeþ. for suche is gras.
Þerfore wheþer me be wel or wo.
I. sei not but Deo gratias.
¶ Þouȝ .i. be riche of gold so red.
And liht to renne as is a ro.
A noþur is boun to begge his bred.
With brestes blak and bleynes blo.
Whon .i. seo goode depart so.
To sum Mon god sent gret solas.
And sum Mon ay to lyue in wo.
Þen sei .i. deo gracias.
¶ Þou he be pore. and lyue in peyn.
A noþur Mon proudeþ. as doþ a poo.
Whon murthe is his and mournyng myn.
As may bifalle. to me and mo.
ȝif fortune wolde. be so my fo.
From me to turne. hire freoly faas.
Siþþe god may sende. boþe weole and wo.
I. sei not. but deo gracias.
¶ A lord of worschupe ȝif .i. ware.
And were falle doun. in a wro.
Sekenesse sitteþ me. so sare.
And serwe wol neiȝ. myn hert slo.
Þus am .i. bounden. from top to to.
And i. turment so. for my trespaas.
ȝit god may loose me. of þat wo.
And þenne .i. say. Deo gracias.
¶ Whon .i. hedde spendyng. here bifore.
Þer wolde no felauschupe. founde me fro.
But herken and hiȝe. to myn horne.
For in myn hond þer stod non ho.
Nou appeereþ. non of þo.
So pouert apayred haþ my plas.
Ho may haue wele withoute wo.
Þerfore .i. sey. Deo gracias.
¶ Almyhti corteis crouned kyng.
God graunt vs grace to rule vs so.
Þat we may come to þi wonyng.
Þere is weole. withouten wo.
Milde maide prey þi sone al so.
Þat he forȝiue vs. vr trespas.
And aftur ward. in-to heuene go.
Þere to synge. Deo gracias.

DIV2.TRAILER: Explicit. A noþer songe of Deo gracias.

DIV2.HEAD: XXIX. A SONG-KNOWE ÞI SELF.

HEADNOTE.P: (Additional MS. 22,283; Brit. Mus. fol. 129, back, col. 1.)

LG.L: In a Pistel þat Poul wrouht.
I. founde hit writen. and seide riht þis.
Vche cristen creature knowen hym self ouht.
His oune vessel. and soþe hit is.
Nere help of hym. þat vs deore bouht.
We were boren to luytel blis.
Whon alle þi goode dedus. beoþ þorw souȝt.
Seche and þou schalt. fynden a-mys.
Eueri mon schuld. knowen his.
And þat is luytel. as .i. trowe.
To teche vr self. crist vs wis.
For vche mon ouȝt hym self to knowe.
¶ Knowe þi self. what þou ware.
Whon þou were. of þi Moder born.
Ho was þi moder. þat þe bare.
And ho was þi fader. þer biforn.
Knowè hou þei beoþ. forþe i-fare.
So schaltou. þeiȝ þou hedde sworn.
Knowe þou come hider. wiþ care.
Þou nost neuer. ȝif þou bide til morn.
Hou lihtly. þou maiȝt be forlorn.
But þou þi synne schryue and schowe.
For lond or kiþ. catel or corn.
Vche Mon ouȝt hym self to knowe.
¶ Knowe þi lyf. hit may not last.
But as a blast. blouh out þi breth.
Tote and by a noþur mon tast.
Riht as a gleirtand glem. hit geth.
What is al. þat forþ is past.
Hit fareþ as fuir of heth.
Þis worldes goode. a way wol hast.
For synnes seekenes. þi soule sleþ.
And þat is. a ful deolful deþ.
Go, saue þi soule and þou be slowe.
With þi Maistrie. medel þi meþ.
For vche mon ouȝt. hym self to knowe.
¶ ȝif þou þi self. knowe con.
Sitte doun. and take countures rounde.
Siþþe furst. þou monnes wit bigon.
Hou ofte synne. þe haþ ibounde.
And for vehe a synne. lay þou doun on.
Til þou þi synnes. haue souȝt vp. and founde.
Counte. þi goode dedes eurichon.
A-bide þere a while. and stunt a stounde.
And ȝif þou fele þe syker and sounde.
Þenke on þi god. as þe wel owe.
And ȝif þou art. in synne ibounde.
Amende þe. and þi self knowe.
Knowe what god. haþ for þe do.
Made þe aftur. his oune liknes.
Seiþe he come. from heuene also.
And diȝed for þe. in gret distres.
For þe he suffred. boþe pyne and wo.
Knowe þou hym. and alle his.
Whoso greueþ hym. is worþi to go.
To helle fuyr. but he hit redres.
And he beo demed. be rihtwisnes.
But his grace is. so wide isowe.
From his wraþe .i. rede vs bles.
For vche mon ouȝt. hym self to knowe.
¶ Knowe þi self. þat þou schalt dye.
But what tyme þou nost neuer ne whenne.
With an twynklyng of an eiȝe.
Eueriday þou hiȝest þe henne.
Þi flesche foode. þe wormes wol fye.
Vche cristen mon. ouȝt þis to kenne.
Loke aboute. and wel aspye.
Þis world doþ but bitraye menne.
And be war of þe fuir. þat euer schal brenne.
And þenk þou regnest here. but a þrowe.
Heuene blisse. þou schat haue þenne.
For vche mon ouȝt. hym self to knowe.
¶ Knowe þi flesche. þat wol rote.
For certes þou maiȝt not longe endure.
And nedes die. hennes þou mote.
Þauȝ þou haue kyngdam and empyre.
And sone þou schalt. be forgote.
So schal souereyn, so schal syre.
Hoso leeueþ not þis .i. trowe he dote.
For eueri mok. most in-to myre.
Preye we to god. vr soules enspire.
Or we bene logged. in eorþe lowe.
Heuene to haue. to vr huire.
For vche mon ouȝt him self to knowe.
¶ Knowe þi kuynde Creatoure.
Knowe what he. for þe dide.
Knowe þis worldly. honoure.
Hou sone þat hit is forþ islyde.
Ende of ioye. is her doloure.
Strengþe stont vs in no stide.
But longyng. and beoing in laboure.
Vr bost vr brag. is sone ouerbide.
Arthur. and Ector. þat we dredde.
Dethe [MS. Aethe] haþ leide hem. wonderly lowe.
Amende þe mon. euene forþ mydde.
For vchemon ouȝte. hym self to knowe.
¶ Þi Concience schal þe saue and deme.
Wheþer þat þou. be ille or good.
Grope aboute and take good ȝeme.
Þer maiȝt þou wite. but þou be wood.
Þer schalt þou þe same seone.
Aske Merci. wiþ mylde mood.
Amende þe. þou wot what .i. mene.
Vche creature þat bereþ. bon and blood.
Prey we to god þat died on Roode.
Ar vr brethe beo. out i. blowe.
Þat cristes face. may bene vr foode.
For vche mon ouȝt. hym self to knowe.

DIV2.TRAILER: Explicit. A song knowe þi self.

HEADNOTE.P: (Additional MS. 22,283; Brit. Mus. fol. 129, back, col. 3.)

LG.L: Whon men beoþ muriest. at heor mele.
With mete and drink. to maken hem glade.
With worschipe. and with worldliche wele.
Þei bene so sette. þei conne not sade.
Þei haue no deynte forto dele.
With þinges þat bene deuotly made.
Þei wene heore honoure and heore hele.
Schal euer last and neuer diffade.
But in heore hertes. i. wolde þei hade.
Whon þei gon ricchest men aray.
Hou sone þat god hem may degrade.
And sum tyme þenke on ȝusturday.
¶ Þis day as leef. we may be liht.
With alle þe murþes þat men may vise.
To Reuele with þise buyrdes briht.
Vche mon gayest on his gise.
At þe last. hit draweþ to niht.
Þat slepe most make. his maistrise.
Whon þat he haþ kud his miht.
Þe morwe he buskeþ vp to rise.
Þenne alle draweþ hem to fantasie.
Wher he is bicomen con no mon say.
And ȝif heo wuste. þei were ful wise.
For al is turned to ȝusterday.
¶ Whoso wolde þenke. vppon þis.
Miht fynde a goode enchesun whi.
To preue þis world. al wey i-wis.
Hit nis but fantum. and feiri.
Þis eorþeli ioie þis worldly blis.
Is but a fykel fantasy.
For nou hit is. and nou hit nis.
Þer may no mon þerinne affy.
Hit schaungeþ so oft and so sodeynly.
To day is here. to morwe a way.
A syker ground who wol him gy.
I. rede he þenke on ȝusterday.
¶ For þer nis non. so strong in stour.
Fro tyme þat he. ful waxen be.
From þat day forþ. eueriche an hour.
Of his strengþe he leost a quantite.
Ne no buyrde so briht in boure.
Of þritti wyntur. i. enseure þe.
Þat heo ne schal fade as a flour.
Luyte. and luyte. leosen hir beute.
Þe soþe ȝe may. ȝor self ise.
Beo ȝor eldres. in goode fay.
Whon ȝe bene grettest in ȝour degre.
I. rede ȝe þenke on ȝusturday.
¶ Nis non so fresch. on fote to fare.
Ne non so feir. on folde to fynde.
Þat þei ne schal on bere. be brouȝt ful bare.
Þis wrecched world nis but a wynde.
Ne non so styf. to stunt ne stare.
Ne non so bold. Beores to bynde.
Þat he naþ warnynges to be ware.
For god is so corteis and so kynde.
Biholde þe lame. þe bedrede. þe blynde.
Þat bit ȝou be war. whil þat ȝe may.
Þei make a Mirour. to ȝor mynde.
To seo þe schap. of ȝusterday.
¶ Þe lyf þat eny mon schal lede.
Beþ certeyn dayes atte last.
Þen most vr terme. schort nede.
Be o day comen. a noþur is past.
Here-of and we wolde. take good hede.
And in vr hertes acountes cast.
Day bi day. withoute drede.
To-ward vr ende. we drawe ful fast.
Þenne schal vr bodies in eorþe be þrast.
Vr Careyns chaunged. vndur clay.
Here of we ouȝte be sore agast.
And we wolde þenke on ȝusterday.
¶ Salomon seide in his poysi.
He holdeþ wel bettre. with an hounde.
Þat is likyng. and Ioly.
And of sekenesse. hol and sounde.
Þen be a leon. þouȝ he ly.
Cold. and ded. vppon þe grounde.
Wher of serueþ. his victori.
Þat was so styf. in vche a stounde.
Þe most fool. i. herde respounde.
Is wysore. whil he lyue may.
Þen he þat hedde. a þousond pounde.
And was buried. ȝusterday.
¶ Socrates seiþ. a word ful wys.
Hit were wel bettre forto se.
A mon þat nou parteþ. and dis.
Þen a fest. of Rialte.
Þe fest wol make. his flesche to ris.
And drawe his herte. to vanite.
Þe body þat on þe bere lis.
Scheweþ þe same þat we schal be.
Þat ferful fit. may no mon fle.
Ne with no whiles. wynne hit a way.
Þerfore among al Iolyte.
Sumtyme þenke on ȝusterday.
¶ But ȝit me meruayles. ouer al.
Þat god let monymon croke and elde.
Whon miht and strengþe is from hem fal.
Þat þei may not. hem self awelde.
And now þise beggers most principal.
Þat good ne profit. may non ȝelde.
To þi purpos vnswere. i. schal.
Whi god sent suche men. boote and belde.
Crist þat made boþe flour and felde.
Let suche men lyue. forsoþe to say.
Whon a ȝonge mon. on hem bihelde.
Scholde seo þe schap. of ȝusterday.
¶ A noþur skil. þer is for whi.
Þat god let suche men lyue so longe.
For þei beoþ triacle. and remedi.
For synful men. þat han don wronge.
In hem. þe seuen dedes of Merci.
A Mon may. fulfille amonge.
And also þis proude men may þerbi.
A feir Mirour vndurfonge.
For þer nis non. so stif ne stronge.
Ne no lady. stout ne gay.
Biholde what ouer hor hed con honge.
And sumtyme þenke on ȝusterday.
¶ I. haue wust. sin. i. couþe meen.
Þat children haþ. bi candel liht.
Heore schadewe on þe walle isen.
And ronne þer aftur. al þe niht.
Bisi aboute. þei han ben.
To cacchen hit with al heore miht.
And whon þei cacchen hit. best wold wen.
Sannest hit schet out. of heore siht.
Þe schadewe cacchen. þei ne myht.
For no lynes. þat þei couþe lay.
Þis schadewe. i. may likne a riht.
To þis world. and ȝusterday.
¶ In-to þis world. whon we beþ brouȝt.
We schul be tempted. to couetyse.
And al þi wit. schal be þorw souȝt.
To more good. þen þou may suffise.
Whon þou þenkest best. in þi þouht.
On richesse. forte regne and rise.
Al þi trauayle. turneþ to nouȝt.
For sodeynly on deþ þou dyese.
Þi lyf þou hast ilad with lyȝes.
So þis world. gon þe bitray.
Þerfore. i. rede þou þis dispise.
And sumtyme þenke on ȝusterday.
¶ Mon, ȝif þi neiȝebor þe manas.
Oþur to culle. oþur to bete.
I. knowe me syker in þe cas.
Þat þou wold drede. þi neiȝebores þrete.
And neuer a day þi dore to pas.
Withoute syker. defense and grete.
And ben purueyed. in vche a plas.
Of sykernes. and helpe to gete.
Þin enemy woltou. not forȝete.
But ay be aferd. of his affray.
Ensaumple here of. i. wol ȝou trete.
To make ȝou þenke. on ȝusterday.
¶ Wel þou wost. withouten fayle.
Þat deþ haþ manast þe to die.
But whon þat he wol þe assayle.
Þat wost þou not. ne neuer may spye.
ȝif þou wost don bi my counsayle.
Wiþ syker defence. be ay redie.
For siker defence. in þis batayle.
Is clene lyf parfit and tyre.
Put þi trust. in godus Mercie.
Hit is þe best. at al assay.
And euer among. þou þe ennuye. [? enmiye]
In-to þis world. and ȝusterday.
¶ Sum men seiþ þat deþ is a þef.
And al vnwarned. wol on hym stele.
And. i. say nay. and make a pref.
Þat deþ is studefast trewe and lele.
And warneþ vche mon. of his gref.
Þat he wol o day. with hym dele.
Þe lyf þat is. to ȝou so leof.
He wol ȝou reue. and eke ȝor hele.
Þis poyntes. may no mon hym repele.
He comeþ so baldely. to pike his pray.
Whon men beoþ murgest. at heor mele.
I. rede ȝe þenke on ȝusterday.

DIV2.HEAD: XXXI. WHY I CAN'T BE A NUN.

LG.L: And whan they had resceyvede her charge,
They spared nether mud ne myer,
But roden over Inglonde brode and large,
To seke owte nunryes in euery schyre:
Her hertys were alwey on her hyre,
And that scheude they wel in her workyng,
For they were as ferfent as ony fyre
To excecute her lordys byddyng.
And schortly to sey, no man abode
That on thys erand schulde be sent.
In-to dyuers schyres dyuers men rode,
And one of hem be-gan in kent.
They token her leue and forthe they went;
And to eche of hem was ȝeven grete hyre,
And there fore they were so feruent
To seke owte nunryes in euery schyre.
But the townes names I ouyr pas,
For and I schulde telle alle in fere,
Hyt were a long tale for to here.
But on a boke I dare well swere,
In gode feythe and on womanhode,
None was forȝete, fer ne nere,
Thorowȝ ynglond long and brode.
[B]ut when they were com home aȝene
That roden owte message to bere,
Than my fader was fulle fayne
And callede hem to hym alle in fere
And seyde, "how sped ȝe there ȝe were,
How faren the nunnes that ȝe cam tylle?"
"Welle, syr," quod they, "and made vs gode chere,
And yowre desyre they wolle fulfylle."
"I thanke hem seres Iwys," quod he,
"Now am I glade, so god me spede:"
And than my fader loked on me,
"Dameselle," quod he, "now take gode hede,
For yowre entent god do yow mede,
ȝe seyde ȝe wolde be a nune
But ȝe may not fulfylle in dede
The purpose that ȝe haue be-gun."
"Fader, quod I, and sore I wept,
Wolle ȝe me here wythe wordys few;
I trow my wylle schalle be accept
Before owre souereyne lorde ihesu,
And to him I am, and wolle be, trew
Wythe alle my wylle and obcervaunce,
And I wolle not chonge hym for no new,
For I loue hym wythe owten variaunce;
And trewly me repenteth fulle sore
That my wylle my not be had."
Than my fader lowȝ and seyde no more,
But went his way and was fulle glade;
But than morned I, and was ryȝt sad,
And in my hert I was fulle wo:
'Alas', I thowȝt, 'my chawnce ys bad,
I trow that fortune be my fo.'
Than hyt befell in a mornyng of may,
In the same ȝere as I seyde be-fore,
My pencyfnes wolde not a-way
But euer waxed more and more,
I walked a-lone and wepte sore
Wythe syhyngys and mornyng chere,
I seyde but lytylle and thowȝt the more,
For what I thowȝt no man myȝt here,
And in a gardyne I sportyd me
Euery day at dyuers howres,
To beholde and for to see
The swete effecte of aprelle flowres,
The fayre herbys and gentyl flowrys
And birde syngyng on euery spray,
But my longyng and my dolowrys
For alle thys sport wolde not away.
The byrdys sate on the bowes grene
And syngyng fulle meryly & made gode chere
Her federys were fulle fayre and schene
And alle they maden mery in her manere.
Than went I in-to a fayre herbere,
And set me on my kneys allone,
To god I made my prayowre,
And on thys wyse I made my mone—
"Lorde god that alle vertu hast
And haddyst wythe-owten begynnyng,
Kepe me that I may lyue chaste
For the corupcion of synnyng;
For thowȝ my fadyr and alle my kyn
For-sake me thus in necessite,
ȝyt I hope suche grace to wyn
That owre lord ihesu wolle resceyue me.
Souereyne lord omnipotent,
Now be my comfort, swete Ihesu.
Before the alle thyng ys present,
Alle that evyr was, and alle þat ys,
Alle that schalle be aftyr thys,
Thow knowest alle thyng bothe most and lest.
Now ihesu kyng of hevyn blys,
Wysse me thy seruant what ys best,
For now I am alle desolate,
And of gode cownesayle destitute.
Lord to my mornyng be mediate,
For thow are oonly my refute,
To the for comfort I make my sute
To haue that ioy that lastythe ay,
For her loue that bare that frute,
Swete ihesu, miserere mei!
I can no more, but trust in the
In whom ys alle wysdom an wyt;
And thow wost what ys best for me,
For alle thyng in thy syȝt ys pyt.
Loo here I thyne hand-mayde syt
Dyspysede and in poynte to spylle;
My cawse to the, lorde, I commytte;
Now do to me aftyr thy wylle."
And at that worde for-feynte I fylle
Among the herbes fresche and fyne;
Vn-to a benche of camomylle
My wofulle hede I dyd inclyne,
And so I lay in fulle grete pyne,
And cowde not cese but alwey wepe,
And sore I syȝhed many a tyme
And prayed my lorde he wolde me kepe.
And at the last a sclepe was Ibrowȝt
And alle a-lone in this gardyne.
And than com a fayre lady, as me thowȝt,
And called me by name 'kateryne',
And seyde "a-wake, dowȝtyr myne,
And to my talkyng take entent;
To bryng thyne hert owte of pyne,
And to comfort the, now haue I ment.
Kateryne", sche sayde, "loke vp and haue"
And than I behelde welle her fygure,—
I pray to god in hevyn her saue,—
For hyt was the most godely creature
That euer I saw, I yow ensuer,
As I wolle telle yow or I go,
For I behelde welle her feture,
Her bewte, and her clothyng also,
And me thowȝt I was as wakyng tho;
And I behelde that lady so
That I forgate alle my mornyng,
For hyt was to me a wondyr thyng
That lady to beholden and see,
Sche was so fayre wythe-owten lesyng
Bothe of clothyng and of bewte,
Thys that was so godely arrayed.
Sche comfortythe me in dyuers wyse,
And spake to me in dyuers wyse,
And bad me anone I schulde aryse.
And me thowȝt I rose and knelyd thryes,
And seyde to her wythe grete reuerence,
"What ys yowr name, dame empryse?"
Sche seyde "my name ys experience;
And, dowȝter, my techyng may not fayle;
For what so I teche, hyt ys fulle trew,
And now at thys tyme for thyne avayle
I am com hedyr on the to rew;
And wythe the help of cryste ihesu
I hope hyt schalle be for the best,
For suche thynges as I schalle the sche,
I tro hyt schalle set thyne hert in rest."
"Thanke yow, lady," quod I than,
"And there-of hertely I yow pray;
And I, as lowly as I can,
Wolle do yow servyse nyȝt and day;
And what ȝe byd me do or say
To yow I promyt obedyence,
And bryng me owte of thys carefulle way,
My gode dere lady experience."
Than me thowȝt sche toke me by the honde
As I knelyd vp-on my kne
And vp a-none sche bad me ryse,
And on thys wyse seyde to me,
"Kateryne, thys day schalt thow see
And howse of wommen reguler,
And diligent loke that thow be,
And note ryȝt welle what þow seest there."
Than me thouȝt sche led me forthe a pace
Thorowȝ a medow fayre and grene,
And sone sche browȝt me to a place,
In erthe ys none so fayre I wene,
Of ryalle byldyng so I mene,
Hyt schyned wythe-owte so fayre and clere,
But syn had made hyt fulle vnclene
Wythe-in, as ȝe schalle aftyr here.
"What place ys thys þat stondythe hyre",
Quod I to hyre þat dyd me lyde.
"Kateryne, sche sayd, we wyl go nere,
And what you seyst, take good hede."
Than at the ȝates in we ȝede,
Boldly as thowȝ we had be at home,
And I thowȝt, 'now cryst vs spede'.
Than to the cloyster sone we com,
For hyt was a howse of nunes in trewthe,
Of dyuers orderys bothe old and yong,
But not welle gouernede, and þat was rowthe,
Aftyr the rewle of sad levyng.
For where that selfe-wylle ys reygnyng,
The whyche causethe dyscord and debate,
And resun hathe none enteryng,
That howse may not be fortunate.
For arystotelle, who so redythe
In the fyrst boke of hys moralite,
Playnely sayethe that euery man nedethe
To be ware of the vnresonabylite
That comethe of the sensualite,
And not hys bestely condiciones sewe,
But let resun haue the soueraynte,
And so he schalle purches vertu.'
But what in that place I saw
That to religion schulde not long,
Peraventure ȝe wolde desyre to know,
And who was dwellyng hem a-mong.
Sum what schalle I telle yow wyth tong,
And sum what cownseyle kepe I schalle,
And so I was tawȝt whan I was yong,
To here and se, and sey not alle.
But there was a lady, that hyȝ dame pride;
In grete reputacion they her toke
And pore dame mekenes sate be syde,
To her vnnethys ony wolde loke,
But alle as who seythe I her forsoke,
And set not by her nether most ne lest;
Dame ypocryte loke vp-on a boke
And bete her selfe vp on the brest.
On euery syde than lokede vp I,
And fast I cast myne ye a-bowte;
Yf I cowde se be-holde or a-spy,
I wolde haue sene dame devowte.
And sche was but wythe few of that rowȝt;
For dame sclowthe and dame veyne glory
By vyolens had put her owte;
And than in my hert I was fulle sory.
But dame envy was there dwellyng
The whyche can sethe stryfe in euery state.
And a nother lady was there wonnyng
That hyȝt dame loue vn-ordynate,
In that place bothe erly and late
Dame lust, dame wantowne, and dame nyce,
They ware so there enhabyted, I wate,
That few token hede to goddys servyse.
Dame chastyte, I dare welle say,
In that couent had lytylle chere,
But oft in poynte to go her way,
Sche was so lytelle beloved there;
But sum her loved in hert fulle dere,
And there weren that dyd not so,
And sum set no thyng by her,
But ȝafe her gode leue for to go.
And at that place I saw muche more,
But alle I thenk not to dyscrye,
But I wolle sey as I seyde be-fore.
And yt ys a poynte of curtesy;
For whoso chateryt lyke a py
And tellethe alle that he herethe and seethe,
He schalle be put owte of company,
And scho the gose, thus wysdum vs lerethe.
And in that place fulle besyly
I walked whyle I myȝt enduer,
And saw how dame enevy
In euery corner had grete cure;
Sche bare the keyes of many a dore.
And than experience to me came,
And seyde, kateryne, I the ensuer,
Thys lady ys but seldom fro home.
Than dame pacience and dame charyte
In that nunry fulle sore I sowȝt;
I wolde fayne haue wyst where they had be,
For in that couent were they nowȝt;
But an owte chamber for hem was wrowȝt,
And there they dweldyn wyth-owtyn stryfe,
And many gode women to them sowȝt
And were fulle wyfulle of her lyfe,
Also a-nother lady there was
That hyȝt dame dysobedyent
And sche set nowȝt by her priores.
And than me thowȝt alle was schent,
For sugettys schulde evyr be dylygent
Bothe in worde, in wylle, and dede,
To plese her souereynes wyth gode entent,
And hem obey, ellys god forbede.
And of alle the defawtes that I cowde se
Thorowȝ schewyng of experience,
Hyt was one of the most that grevyd me,
The wantyng of obedyence.
For hyt schulde be chese in consciens,
Alle relygius rule wytnesseth the same,
And when I saw her in no reverence,
I myȝt no lenger abyde for schame,
For they setten not by obedyence.
And than for wo myne hert gan blede,
Ne they hadden her in no reuerence,
But few or none to her toke hede.
And than I sped me thens a grete spede,
That couent was so fulle of syn;
And than experience dyd me lede
Owte at the ȝates there we com In.
And when we were both wyth-owte,
Vp on the gras we setten vs downe,
And then we he-helde the place abowte,
And there we talkeden as vs lest.
And than I prayed experience for to haue wyst
Why sche schewed me thys nunery,
Sche seyde "now we bene here in rest,
I thenk for to tellen the why.
Thy fyrst desyre and thyne entent
Was to bene a nune professede,
And for thy fader wolde not consent,
Thyne hert wyth mornyng was sore oppressede,
And thow wyst not what to do was best;
And I seyde, I wolde cese thy grevawnce,
And now for the most part in euery cost
I haue schewed the nunnes gouernawnce.
For as thow seest wyth-in yonder walle
Suche bene the nunnes in euery warde,
As for the most part, I say not alle,
God forbede, for than hyt were harde,
For sum bene devowte, holy, and towarde,
And holden the ryȝt way to blysse;
And sum bene feble, lewde, and frowarde,
Now god amend that ys amys!
And now kateryne, I haue alle do
For thy comfort that longeth to me,
And now let vs aryse and go
Vn-to the herber there I com to the."
Than in thys herber sche let be me.
I thanked her wyth grete reuerence,
I pray to god I-blessyd be sche,
Thys fayre lady experience.
And whan sche was gone, I wakede anone.
And I thowȝ how I may gouerned be,
For nun wold I neuere be none,
For suche defawtes that I haue see.
But ȝyf they myȝt amendyd be,
And forsake her syn both day and nyȝt,
God ȝyf me grace that day to se,
And ellys hyt wolle not be a ryȝt.
But here perauenture sum man wolde say,
And to hys conceyte so hyt schulde seme,
That I forsoke sone a perfyte way
For a fantesy or for a dreme.
For dreme was hyt none, ne fantasye,
Hyt was vn-to me a gratius mene,

LG.L: Pleynely go rede hyt wh . . .
And hyt ys wretyn in Genesye,
In the fowre and thyrty Chapytylle,
How dyna, for sche bode not stylle
But went owte to see thynges in veyne,
Sche was defowled a-ȝenst her wylle,
And there-fore thowsandys of peple were sclayn.
Yowre barbe, your wymppylle and your vayle,
Yowre mantelle and yowre devowte clothyng,
Maketh men wyth-owten fayle
To wene ȝe be holy in levyng.
And so hyt ys an holy thyng
To bene in habyte reguler;
Than, as by owtewarde aray in semyng,
Beth so wyth-in my ladyes dere.
A fayre garlond of yve grene
Whyche hangeth at a taverne dore,
Hyt ys a false token as I wene,
But yf there be wyne gode and sewer;
Ryȝt so but ȝe your vyces for-bere,
And let alle lewde custom be broken,
So god me spede, I yow ensewer
Ellys yowre habyte ys no trew token
. . . . . yng . . . nde gode levyng,
. . yf they be wyth-in the contrary,
In holy schrypture wyth-owte lesyng
They bene called the chyldryn of false ypocrasy.
Now, ladyes, taketh gode hede to thys exhortacion
That I haue tawȝt yow in thys lore,
And beholde the gode conuersacion
Of gode women here be-fore,
Fulle holy vyrgynes many a store,
The whyche levedyn here relygyiusly,
And now in ioy and blysse therefore
They haue possession enlesly,—
Seynte clare and seynte edyth also,
Seynte scolastica and seynte Brigytte,
That weren MS. wereren. professed in nunnes habyte.
They fulle besy were wyth alle her wytte
To be ware of syn, and fle there froo,
And now for evyr they bene qwyte
From alle maner sorow and woo,—
Seynte audre, seynte freswyth, & seynte Emerlde (?)
Seynte wythbuge & seynte Myldrede,
Seynte sexburge & seynte Ermenylde,—
Of alle these holy women we rede.

erþ askeþ carayne. of king and of kniȝt.

LG.L: Fur in see bi west spayngne.
Is a lond ihote cokaygne.
Þer nis lond under heuen-riche.
Of wel of godnis hit iliche.
Þoȝ paradis be miri and briȝt.
Cokaygn is of fairir siȝt.
What is þer in paradis.
Bot grasse and flure and grene-ris.
Þoȝ þer be ioi and grete dute.
Þer nis mete bote frute.
Þer n'is halle, bure, no benche.
Bot watir, man-is þursto quenche.
Beþ þer no man but two.
Hely and enok also.
Clinglich may hi go.
Whar þer woniþ men no mo.
¶ In cokaygne is met and drink.
Wiþ vte care. how and swink.
Þe met is trie. þe drink is clere.
To none. russin, and sopper.
I sigge for soþ, boute were.
Þer n'is lond on erthe is pere.
Vnder heuen n'is lond iwisse.
Of so mochil ioi and blisse.
¶ Þer is mani swete siȝte.
Al is dai, n'is þer no niȝte.
Þer n'is baret noþer strif.
N'is þer no deþ, ac euer lif.
Þer n'is lac of met no cloþ.
Þer n'is man no womman wroþ.
Þer n'is serpent, wolf no fox.
Hors, no capil, kowe, no ox.
Þer n'is schepe. no swine no gote.
No non horwȝ-la, god it wot.
Nother harate, nother stode.
Þe lond is ful of oþer gode.
N'is þer flei. fle, no lowse.
In cloþ, in toune. bed, no house.
Þer n'is dunnir, slete, no hawle.
No non vile worme no snawile.
Non non storme, rein, no winde.
Þer n'is man no womman blinde.
Ok al is game, Ioi, and gle.
Wel is him þat þer mai be.
¶ Þer beþ riuers gret and fine.
Of oile, melk, honi and wine.
Watir seruiþ þer to no þing.
Bot to siȝt and to waiissing.
Þer is maner frute.
Al is solas and dedute.
¶ Þer is a wel fair abbei.
Of white monkes and of grei.
Þer beþ bowris and halles.
Al of pasteiis beþ þe walles.
Of fleis, of fisse, and rich met.
Þe likfullist þat man mai et.
Fluren cakes beþ þe scingles alle.
Of cherche. cloister. boure. and halle.
Þe pinnes beþ fat podinges.
Rich met to princeȝ and kinges.
Man mai þer-of et inoȝ.
Al wiþ riȝt, and noȝt wiþ woȝ.
Al is commune to ȝung and old.
To stoute and sterne, mek and bold.
¶ Þer is a cloister fair and liȝt.
Brod and lang, of sembli siȝt.
Þe pilers of þat cloistre alle
Beþ i-turned of cristale.
Wiþ har-las and capitale.
Of grene Jaspe and rede corale.
In þe praer is a tre.
Swiþe likful for to se.
Þe rote is gingeuir and galingale.
Þe siouns beþ al sedwale.
Trie maces beþ þe flure.
Þe rind, canel of swet odur.
Þe frute gilofre of gode smakke.
Of cucubes þer n'is no lakke.
Þer beþ rosis of rede ble.
And lilie likful for to se.
Þai faloweþ neuer day no niȝt.
Þis aȝt be a swet[e] siȝt.
¶ Þer beþ .iiij. willis in þe abbei.
¶ Of triacle and halwei.
Of baum and ek piement.
Euer ernend to riȝt rent.
Of þai stremis al þe molde.
Stonis preciuse and golde.
Þer is saphir and vniune.
Carbuncle and astiune.
Smaragde. lugre. and prassiune.
Beril. onix. topasiune.
Ametist and crisolite.
Calcedun and epetite.
¶ Þer beþ briddes mani and fale.
Þrostil, þruisse, and niȝtingale.
Chalandre and wodwale.
And oþer briddes wiþout tale.
Þat stinteþ neuer by har miȝt.
Miri to sing dai and niȝt.
[Here a few lines seem to be lost.]
¶ ȝite I do ȝow mo to witte.
Þe Gees irostid on þe spitte.
Fleeȝ to þat abbai, god hit wot.
And grediþ 'gees al hote, al hot.'
Hi bringeþ garlek gret plente.
Þe best idiȝt þat man mai se.
Þe leuerokes þat beþ cuþ.
Liȝtiþ adun to man-is muþ.
Idiȝt in stu ful swiþe wel.
Pudrid wiþ gilofre and canel.
N'is no spech of no drink.
Ak take inoȝ wiþ-vte swink.
¶ Whan þe monkes geeþ to masse.
All þe fenestres þat beþ of glasse.
Turneþ in to cristal briȝt.
To ȝiue monkes more liȝt.
When þe masses beþ iseiid.
And þe bokes up ileiid.
Þe cristal turniþ in to glasse.
In state þat hit raþer wasse.
¶ Þe ȝung monkes euch dai.
Aftir met goþ to plai.
N'is þer hauk no fule so swifte.
Bettir fleing bi þe lifte.
Þan þe monkes heiȝ of mode.
Wiþ har sleuis and har hode.
¶ Whan þe abbot seeþ ham flee.
Þat he holt for moch glee.
Ak naþeles al þar amang.
He biddiþ ham liȝt to eue-sang.
Þe monkes liȝtiþ noȝt adun.
Ac furre fleeþ in o randun.
¶ Whan þe abbot him iseeþ.
Þat is monkis fram him fleeþ.
He takeþ maidin of þe route.
And turniþ vp her white toute.
And betiþ þe taburs wiþ is hond.
To make is monkes liȝt to lond.
¶ Whan is monkes þat iseeþ.
To þe maid dun hi fleeþ.
And geþ þe wench al abute.
And þakkeþ al hir white toute.
And siþ aftir her swinke.
Wendith meklich hom to drinke.
And geth to har collacione.
A wel fair processione.
¶ Anoþer abbei is þerbi.
For soth a gret fair nunnerie.
Up a riuer of swet milke.
Whar is plente grete of silk.
Whan þe somer-is dai is hote.
Þe ȝung nunnes takith a bote.
And doth ham forth in that riuer.
Bothe with oris and with stere.
When hi beth fur from the abbei.
Hi makith ham nakid for to plei.
And lepith dune in-to the brimme.
And doth ham sleilich for to swimme.
Þe ȝung monkes MS. monkeþ. þat hi seeth.
Hi doth ham up, and forþ hi fleeþ.
And commiþ to þe nunnes anon.
And euch monke him taketh on.
And snellich berith forth har prei.
To the mochil grei abbei.
And techith the nunnes an oreisun.
With iambleue vp and dun.
¶ Þe monke þat wol be stalun gode.
And kan set a-riȝt is hode.
He schal hab wiþute danger.
.xii. wiues euche ȝere.
Al þroȝ riȝt and noȝt þroȝ grace.
For to do him silf solace.
And þilk monk þat clepiþ best.
And doþ his likam al to rest.
Of him is hoppe, god hit wote.
To be sone uadir abbot.
¶ Whose wl com þat lond to.
Ful grete penance he mot do.
Seue ȝere in swine-is dritte.
He mot wade, wol ȝe i-witte.
Al anon up to þe chynne.
So he schal þe lond[e] winne.
¶ Lordinges gode and hend.
Mot ȝe neuer of world wend.
For ȝe stond to ȝure cheance.
And fulfille that penance.
Þat ȝe mote þat lond ise.
And neuer more turne a-ȝe.
Prey we god so mote hit be.
Amen, per seinte charite.
Bissop lorles.
Kyng redeles.
ȝung man rechles.
Old man witles.
Womman ssamles.
I swer bi heuen kyng.
Þos beþ fiue liþer þing.
